Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the great challenges for the scientific community over the next decade is to provide useful guidance to society regarding the implications of global climate change, including the substantial uncertainties involved. Moreover, the methods by which that information is communicated have the power to shape public attitudes and response. This project is designed to clarify the relationships between specific methods of climate communication, cognitive processes, attitudes and decisions. The project focuses on four key factors in climate mitigation choices 1) trust in climate projections, 2) concern about climate change 3) self-efficacy with respect to climate change mitigation efforts (whether one feels that one can have an impact) and 4) causal understanding of the mechanisms that underlie climate change. A series of experiments, using a wide range of methodologies, will test the influence of communications strategies on each of these factors as well as whether they interact with participant characteristics such as partisanship, age and gender. Effective climate change communication is a critical challenge for society. It requires transforming complex scientific information, including uncertainty information, into understandable yet relevant projections for a wide range of users in both public and private decisions. This project informs the design of such communications in the context of climate change as well as in other domains.


Experimental procedures test whether climate projections that include uncertainty estimates enhance user trust, the perception of scientific consensus, decision quality and the role of immediate feedback on some of these effects. Experiments also test the role of availability (recent experience with weather consistent with global warming) on risk perception and decisions. Four key communication strategies are explored. This research will test whether 1) the inclusion of uncertainty estimates in climate projections increases trust or impacts the perception of scientific consensus, 2) reducing the level of abstraction impacts mental representations, concern, self-efficacy, or decisions 3) descriptions of extreme weather events consistent with climate change (e.g. heat waves) increase concern or climate friendly choices, 4) causal explanations enhance trust in climate projections or self-efficacy.Furthermore, this project conducts the first experimental comparison of the impact of availability from experience and availability from description. If the latter is effective it may be useful in counteracting the psychological consequences of experience inconsistent with global warming. This project also provides a first experimental test of the impact of causal explanations on trust in climate projections and on self-efficacy with respect to climate mitigation efforts. This project tests whether abstraction in mental representations can be altered with simple communication techniques using a repeated measures design, whether observed changes endure over time, and whether they influence concern about climate change, self-efficacy, and decision-making. By investigating these general mechanisms, the project adds to the scientific understanding of the ways in which people comprehend, evaluate and choose how to act upon predictive communications in risky contexts, advancing both risk communication and decision sciences. Effective climate change communication is a critical challenge requiring transforming complex scientific information, including uncertainty information, into understandable yet relevant projections for a wide range of users in both public and private decisions. The results of this work will inform the design of climate communications as well as predictions and forecasts in a wide range of domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated people?s understanding of climate change and tested several strategies for communicating climate information. Communication strategies were identified that appear to increase people?s understanding, perception of the trustworthiness of climate projections and in some cases, concern about climate change. In the process, the research conducted in this project clarified some of the psychological mechanisms that underpin attitudes toward climate change. In addition, a robust approach to measuring how people think about climate change mitigation strategies was developed.

In four experiments, two with nationally representative samples, respondents trusted climate projections expressing uncertainty significantly more than projections that provided a single value implying an exact outcome. This was true across the political spectrum. Here, uncertainty was expressed as a range of values with a 90% chance of including the outcome (90% predictive interval). Importantly, 90% predictive intervals increased respondents??especially conservatives??perception of the competence and understanding of climate scientists, suggesting that the mechanism by which uncertainty estimates increase trust is through greater respect for climate scientists. Surprisingly, in both nationally representative samples, 90% predictive intervals also increased, rather than decreased, the perception of scientific consensus about climate change, particularly among conservatives.

In addition, uncertainty estimates improved decisions. A series of five experiments investigated the impact of climate communication on seasonal crop choices.  Results suggested that participants made better decisions when using predictions with uncertainty estimates. Moreover, uncertainty estimates neutralized the largely unconscious but negative influence of recent weather events on participants? climate-related decisions.  

Taken together these results suggest that people understand that predictions involve uncertainty and climate projections that acknowledge and quantify the uncertainty will be better received and allow people to make better decisions, than best estimate predictions that imply certainty. Moreover probabilistic predictions may highlight the fact that there is uncertainty in the consequences rather than in the fact of global warming.

Other studies in this project suggested that emphasizing concreteness in climate communication might be beneficial. Two different sets of survey experiments demonstrated that information intended to increase concrete thinking about climate change tended to increase concern and policy support among information recipients, especially those with a conservative political ideology. Although the effects were weak and dissipated after a few days, asking survey participants to describe how people try to slow or stop climate change?intended to trigger concrete thinking?increased support for carbon emissions reduction policies.  In addition, experimental studies in which participants were informed of the consequences of climate change, projections describing concrete events (increased floods or heat waves) were judged more trustworthy and generated more concern than abstract expressions such as average temperature increases, particularly among Republicans. These results suggest that thinking concretely about climate change or receiving projections of consequences that one experiences on a day-to-day basis, are particularly effective in communicating climate change, especially to those who might be skeptics.

The survey research mentioned above also showed that people distinguished between effectiveness and ease of implementation when judging actions to reduce climate change. Support for public policy on climate change was strongly associated with perceptions that government and collective climate change mitigation actions are effective. However, even taking this and other factors (e.g. political leaning and knowledge about climate change) into account, those who perceived undertaking actions personally as easy were more likely to support climate change mitigation polices. Together these results suggest focusing risk communication and management efforts on: (a) how climate change might be slowed or stopped, in particular on what government actions will likely be effective at achieving climate change mitigation and how to make them more effective, and (b) how easy it is to take individual actions, and how to make them easier. 

This research project also revealed some gaps in people?s understanding. In aggregate, survey respondents? judgments of effectiveness did not align with the science on what strategies are more or less likely to mitigate climate change.  Moreover, few respondents understood that concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, as well as global average temperature, will continue to rise long after emissions reductions begin (hundreds of years). However a simple paragraph explanation of the delay increased understanding: five times as many people were able to correctly identify the period of delay after reading it. Moreover, increased understanding of the delay changed attitudes, particularly among conservatives, who were significantly less likely to endorse a ?wait and see? strategy after reading the delay explanation. This is important because it suggests that increases in understanding might help people appreciate the scope of anthropogenic climate change, regardless of prior beliefs.

In sum, this work has uncovered several important approaches to communicating information about climate change to non-experts, based on a better understanding of how people think about these issues, that has potential to increase their understanding and trust in climate science and may affect their level of concern.
